subject: Don't use CLASSPATH (Re: [junit] java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:)
msgSnippet: ... Please note that using the CLASSPATH environment variable, rather than the -classpath switch to the java interpreter, is unnecessarily changing global
messageBody:
Subhendu Paul wrote:
> Hi ,
> You can use a cmd file to launch ur application.
> place the cmd file where your class files are present
> Than populate the cmd file with the followings: Change where u need
>
> REM start
>
> SET JAVA_HOME=C:\jdk1.4.2_02
> SET PATH=%JAVA_HOME%/bin
> SET CLASSPATH=
> SET CLASSPATH=%CLASSPATH%;<PATH OF JUNIT>/junit.jar
> SET CLASSPATH=%CLASSPATH%;<path of your
> WPFStatDescriptor>/WPFStatDescriptor.class
> SET CLASSPATH=%CLASSPATH%;<path of other jar or class>/file name
> SET CLASSPATH=%CLASSPATH%;.
>
> java <class file to be run> <arguement>
>
> pause
>
> REM end

Please note that using the CLASSPATH environment variable, rather than
the -classpath switch to the java interpreter, is unnecessarily changing
global data. (Environment variables are just global variables for your
operating system.) I /certainly/ don't recommend changing the PATH
variable this way: as long as the command window is open, you won't be
able to launch any other software on your machine from that window.

Instead, do this:

SET JAVA_HOME=C:\jdk1.4.2_02
SET JUNIT_HOME=wherever you unpacked JUnit to
SET PATH=%PATH%;%JAVA_HOME%\bin

[Note this adds the java interpreter to your PATH without disturbing the
previous value of PATH]

java -classpath
%JUNIT_HOME%\junit.jar;[your-class-files];[other-jars-you-need]
WPFStatDescriptor
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
